section.title: Manipulating the 3D Orbit View
section.para: GMAT's OrbitView resource offers a three-dimensional realistic view of your mission trajectory in any coordinate system or viewpoint you choose. The view itself can be manipulated using the mouse. Starting from the default mission:

step.para: Click Run. This will run the mission and will result in a DefaultOrbitView window and a DefaultGroundTrackPlot window on the GMAT desktop. The default view is centered at the Earth, in an Earth-centered inertial reference frame.
With the left mouse button, drag in the DefaultOrbitView window. This will rotate the view about the center of the active coordinate system (in this case, the center of the Earth).
With the right mouse button, drag left-to-right. This will zoom the view out from the center of the active coordinate system. Dragging right-to-left will zoom the view in.
With the wheel button (or middle button), drag up and down. This will rotate the view about an axis perpendicular to the screen.

section.title: Configuring the Ground Track Plot
section.para: GMAT's ground track plot can display one or more spacecraft on a two-dimensional map of a celestial body. You can choose which spacecraft are displayed, and which celestial body to use. Keeping the Earth as the central body, let's add a second spacecraft to the default plot. Starting with the default mission, first add a new spacecraft:

step.para: Right-click the Spacecraft folder and click Add Spacecraft to add Spacecraft1.
In the Mission tree, double-click Propagate1.
Under Spacecraft List, click ... to the left of DefaultSC.
In the Available SpaceObject list, click Spacecraft1 and click the -> button to move it to the SpaceObject Selected list. Then click OK. This adds Spacecraft1 to the Spacecraft List for Propagate1.
Click Apply, then click OK.

section.para: Then add the new spacecraft to the ground track plot:

step.para: In the Resources tree, in the Output folder, double-click DefaultGroundTrackPlot.
In the Selected Objects list, select Spacecraft1.

section.para: After the run is complete, the DefaultGroundTrackPlot window will show the trajectory of the default spacecraft and Spacecraft1 on a map of Earth.

section.title: Creating a 2D Plot
section.para: GMAT offers an XYPlot resource that allows you to visualize the relationship between multiple parameters (for example, orbit altitude and time). Starting from the default mission:

step.para: In the Resources tree, right-click the Output folder, point to Add, and click XYPlot.
Double-click the new XYPlot1 resource. The default y-axis parameter is the Cartesian "X" position of the spacecraft.
Click Edit Y to change the y-axis parameter.
In the Selected Value(s) list, click DefaultSC.EarthMJ2000Eq.X and click <- to remove it from the list.
In the Object Properties list, click Altitude.
In the Central Body list, make sure Earth is selected, then click -> to add it to the Selected Value(s) list.
Click OK in the ParameterSelectDialog window, then click OK again in the XYPlot - XYPlot1 window.
